description: Dephasing (also called phase damping or T2 decay) describes the loss of quantum coherence without energy exchange. The off-diagonal elements of the density matrix decay exponentially while the diagonal elements (populations) remain unchanged.

Physically, dephasing arises from fluctuations in the qubit's energy splitting, causing the phase to undergo a random walk. This is the dominant decoherence mechanism in many qubit platforms and is characterized by the T2 coherence time.
Pure dephasing (T2*) refers to inhomogeneous dephasing from static frequency variations, while T2 includes both pure dephasing and contributions from T1 relaxation: 1/T2 = 1/(2T1) + 1/T2*.

properties.Parameters: p ∈ [0, 0.5] or λ ∈ [0, 1] = dephasing strength; T2 = coherence time
properties.Fixed points: All diagonal states (classical mixtures of |0⟩ and |1⟩)

physical_examples: Fluctuating magnetic fields in superconducting qubits
Laser phase noise in trapped ions
Nuclear spin bath in solid-state qubits (NV centers)
qem_considerations: Dynamical decoupling is highly effective against low-frequency dephasing noise
Echo sequences (Hahn echo, CPMG) can refocus pure dephasing
Pauli twirling symmetrizes dephasing into depolarizing-like noise
ZNE works but may require careful noise scaling if T2 is time-dependent
